meta.title: Design for How People Think: Using Brain Science to Build Better Products
meta.author: John Whalen, PhD

parts.title: Introduction to Why Design and Psychology Matter
parts.body: The preface introduces why the author wrote this book, emphasizing the application of psychology in product design. Many people are surprised that a psychologist can contribute to this field, often asking if they're being analyzed. The book provides a path for designing great experiences by combining various cognitive processes and senses. It highlights that people aren't always aware of their own mental processes, like recognizing colors without conscious awareness. The author, trained in cognitive science, shares insights to improve products, aiming to help product managers and designers identify these cognitive aspects and use interviews to enhance the design process, ensuring products meet the audience's needs effectively. This hands-on, practical guide is meant for professionals eager to create exceptional, memorable experiences. The Six Minds framework outlined aims to better understand and segment audience needs for successful product development.

parts.title: Preface: Engaging Psychologists and Cognitive Scientists
parts.body: In a practical book, the author can't cover all the nuances of the mind/brain but aims to communicate relevant information on designing products and services with an understanding of cognitive processes. The goal is to have a psychologically driven design process and integrate what we know about our minds into product design. The author encourages feedback from psychologists and cognitive scientists to refine his approach.

parts.title: Memory, Semantics, and Expectations
parts.body: Memory and perception often work in abstract ways rather than detailed ones. People use stereotypes, conceptual memories, and mental models to quickly process visual scenes and interactions. For example, when asked to distinguish a US penny from similar images, most people struggle because their memory doesn't store all the specific details of the coin; it stores a general concept of it. The chapter also discusses the phenomenon of boundary extension, where the mind fills in gaps beyond the edges of a scene based on assumptions. This cognitive tendency can be applied positively in product and service design by creating experiences that align with users' stereotypes and expectations—leading to a more intuitive and trustworthy interaction without needing thorough instructions or explanations.

parts.title: Language and Semantic Design in Communication
parts.body: In this section, we focus on language and semantics in design. Language helps us understand how audiences perceive our products. But words can have different meanings for different people. Laypeople and experts might use different terms, like in healthcare jargon. This impacts product trust and experience. Communication can fail when overusing jargon or misaligning with consumer understanding. This applies to texting habits, where terms vary by culture or age. Designers should ensure people feel like 'you're speaking my language' to create comfort. Notably, translations can alter meanings in different regions, like a Chesterfield in Canada is a couch in the US. Interviews help identify the exact terms clients use, bridging the experience divide.

parts.title: Unlocking User Needs Through Contextual Interviews
parts.body: This section delves into contextual interviews, which combine watching and interviewing people in their natural settings to uncover the "why" behind their behaviors. Unlike traditional focus groups and surveys, contextual interviews help reveal unconscious actions and nuances in customer behavior, allowing for a deep understanding needed for successful product design. By observing superusers and the environments where users live, researchers can gather critical insights into inefficiencies and innovations that are often overlooked. This hands-on approach helps in stepping into users' minds, adapting a customer-centric perspective, and uncovering hidden opportunities to enhance user experiences.

parts.title: Understanding User Wayfinding
parts.body: Wayfinding involves understanding where users think they are in virtual or physical space, how they expect to navigate from Point A to Point B, and the cues they use to determine their location. In product design, it is crucial to incorporate virtual signposts or cues to help users orient themselves and know their path within a system. Understanding users’ expectations and how they fill in gaps in their navigation is vital. In terms of navigation strategies, users may rely on external tools like search engines for assistance. When designing products or services, it is important to consider the entire ecosystem and non-obvious pathways users might take based on their past experiences or assumptions. Observing users can reveal unexpected workarounds and "tricks" they use, which help in tailoring better interaction designs that meet user needs and expectations.

parts.title: Exploring User Emotion in Product Design
parts.body: This section delves into emotion as one of the six key factors influencing how users interact with products. It suggests considering emotions on three levels: Appeal (what instantly attracts customers), Enhance (factors that add meaningful value over time), and Awaken (elements that align with users’ deeper aspirations and fears). Understanding these dimensions helps design products that cater to immediate reactions as well as long-term desires and anxieties. This approach uses insights from Daniel Kahneman about loss and gain, emphasizing the importance of understanding users' fears alongside their goals.

parts.title: Emotions and User Interface Design
parts.body: The content discusses emotional impact on financial decisions and user interface design. Customers reacted emotionally to credit-related issues like identity theft, displaying fear and anxiety. This influenced their decision-making, showing the powerful role of emotions in consumer behavior. Designers must address these emotions to restore trust and improve experiences. In user interface design, the Six Minds framework helps understand user behavior and design better. It involves aspects like language, emotion, and wayfinding. By analyzing these, designers can identify user segments to create tailored product experiences, enhancing usability and satisfaction.

parts.title: Using the Six Minds in the Double Diamond Process
parts.body: In this section, the Double Diamond design process is introduced, which includes: Discover, Define, Develop, and Deliver. Using the Six Minds method helps to efficiently empathize with user needs during the discovery and definition stages. The aim is to identify opportunities to appeal, enhance, and awaken audience passions, thus refining problem-solving before pursuing design solutions. In the second diamond (develop and deliver), vision/attention, wayfinding, memory, and problem solving are key to informing and constraining design choices by understanding how users interact with products.

parts.title: Designing with Six Minds Framework
parts.body: You're equipped to design experiences using the "Six Minds" framework, resulting in better, faster design outcomes with less debate. This chapter summarizes the journey so far and previews possible outcomes from employing the Six Minds. Unique to this approach is the inclusion of empathy at various cognitive levels—acknowledging not just the user’s functional problems but also considering cognitive systems like language, decision-making, and emotional qualities during design. Every “experience” entails numerous “micro-experiences” that collectively shape the perception of a singular event, like the series of experiences during an airport visit. Recognizing that experiences are often a series of interconnected moments prompts us to consider the cumulative impact while designing.
